data.title: Your network inside the business
data.paper_abstract: This article provides advice for managers on how to expand their influence within their organization by building relationships with staff in other departments. By doing so, managers can gain firsthand experience of challenges faced by other teams, participate in strategic discussions, and increase their profile in the company. The article offers tips for getting introduced to the right people, such as asking for recommendations from peers and line managers and introducing oneself via email.
data.subject: Building your influence, network, connections

data.title: Culture
data.paper_abstract: This article explores what company culture is and how it is fostered within technology companies. The author highlights the importance of a compelling vision and purpose for the company, which defines the direction and guides decision-making. Culture emerges from interactions within the company and between the company and the outside world, and is fostered by caring and challenging relationships between individuals. The article emphasizes that perks do not make a strong culture, and that a company can still be dysfunctional despite offering nice benefits.
data.subject: Work culture, organizational culture, values

data.title: The Trichotomy of Control
data.paper_abstract: This article discusses the Trichotomy of Control - a concept in Stoic philosophy that states that there are three types of things in the world: things that are completely under our control, things that are not under our control, and things that are partially under our control. The author applies this concept to engineering management, arguing that focusing on things outside of our control, such as the behavior of others, can lead to frustration and anxiety. Instead, managers should focus on the things that are within their control, such as their own behavior and actions, and seek to influence the things that are partially under their control. By doing so, managers can reduce stress and be more effective in their roles. The article offers practical tips for applying the Trichotomy of Control to engineering management, such as reframing problems in terms of what is and is not under our control, and focusing on the process rather than the outcome.
data.subject: Engineering management, administration

data.title: Rockstars and superstars
data.paper_abstract: This blog discusses how engineers can work towards the individual contributor (IC) track or the management track, and how it is important to identify whether high performers are rockstars or superstars. Rockstars are motivated by being consistent, focused experts, while superstars thrive on new opportunities and variety in their work. Superstars may find stagnation frustrating, while rockstars may become frustrated by changes in circumstances. It is important to understand what motivates each type of performer to ensure they are happy and fulfilled in their roles and to place them in projects and teams where they will perform their best.
data.subject: Career progression

data.title: Wobble
data.paper_abstract: This blog post on The Engineering Manager discusses the challenges of dealing with uncertainty and high emotion in management positions. The author uses the metaphor of a jelly mold to illustrate how organizations can 'wobble' under the weight of unstructured and emotional input, particularly at higher levels of the organization. The post provides guidance for managers on how to prevent this wobble by practicing emotional intelligence, judgment, and support when difficult situations arise. The author emphasizes the importance of mindful listening and observation, digesting information before communicating it to your team, reframing messages to focus on the positive, and building a peer support network.
data.subject: Organizational design, emotional intelligence, judgment

data.title: Fast-forwarding decision making
data.paper_abstract: The article discusses how organizations waste time in decision making by engaging in the theatre of decision making, which creates delay rather than progress. The author advises holding oneself accountable for making decisions and progressing discussions as quickly as possible by being creative about ways of shaving minutes, hours, and days from a decision point.
data.subject_orig: decision making, progress, delay, accountability, creativity
data.subject: decision making, progress, delay, accountability, creativity

data.title: Scrutiny and Judgement
data.paper_abstract: The scrutiny and judgement faced by public figures is not unique to them. As you progress in your management career, you will find that senior positions invite more scrutiny from your colleagues. The visibility of those in power encourages scrutiny, and during good times, they can be fantastic role models. But during bad times, fingers will be pointed at them, despite the net result of the current situation being generated by the whole organization. Coping strategies for those in positions of power include compartmentalizing their personality into their "work" self and their "home" self, but it can become exhausting. Judgement can come from both directions, and to deal with it, one must be themselves, warts and all.
data.subject_orig: scrutiny, judgement, management, leadership, coping strategies
data.subject: scrutiny, judgement, management, leadership, coping strategies

data.title: The Stick
data.paper_abstract: The article discusses the use of the "stick" approach to motivate teams to work harder or faster. It explores the reasons why teams may be asked to work harder and the reasons why the stick approach may not work for software engineering teams. The article suggests that the stick approach is not effective for teams that are in an industry where demand for talent is high and where employees are self-motivated.
data.subject_orig: stick approach, software engineering, motivation, talent, self-motivated
data.subject: stick approach, software engineering, motivation, talent, self-motivated

data.title: Mental Model: Prioritization and Learning
data.paper_abstract: The blog post discusses the phases of learning a new skill, using software development as an example. It begins with making things work, then making them correct, followed by making them usable and optimizing them. Finally, aesthetics is considered.
data.subject_orig: mental model, prioritization, learning, software development, aesthetics, usability, optimization, functionality
data.subject: mental model, prioritization, learning, software development, aesthetics, usability, optimization, functionality
